close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (complete definition, all fields used here)
explanation:
To judge whether any code in MHD_stop_daemon is unreachable we need the exact structure, macros and helper functions that determine control flow at compile- and run-time:

- struct MHD_Daemon: fields (shutdown, master, options, worker_pool, worker_pool_size, tid, was_quiesced, listen_fd, itc, epoll_fd, epoll_upgrade_fd, connections_head, cleanup_head, suspended_connections_head, new_connections_head, urh_head, have_dhparams, https_mem_dhparams, priority_cache, x509_cred, psk_cred, digest_auth_random_copy, nnc, locks, etc.) are used in all branch conditions; their types/initial invariants determine which branches can execute.
- mhd_assert: may be a no-op or aborting check; its definition is needed to know whether asserted branches can be relied on or produce aborts (affects reachability of subsequent code).
- MHD_PANIC: typically aborts/longjmps; needed to know whether code after a panic call is reachable.
- MHD_INVALID_SOCKET: value used to decide whether shutdown/close calls or asserts are reached.
- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_ITC_IS_INVALID_: control whether inter-thread communication paths (itc) are taken; needed to know which blocks are reachable.
- MHD_itc_activate_, MHD_itc_destroy_chk_: behavior and return semantics determine whether failure paths and subsequent MHD_PANIC paths are possible.
- MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_, MHD_thread_handle_ID_join_thread_: determine whether thread-related branches (join/valid-handle) are taken and whether join can fail (causing panic).
- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_, MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_: macros/functions that indicate runtime mode; they gate large alternative code paths (threaded vs non-threaded, epoll vs non-epoll) so are essential to detect unreachable branches.
- MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_: their behavior (e.g. abort on error) can affect reachability of following code.
- close_all_connections: called in the non-threaded path; its implementation may call __builtin_unreachable or otherwise affect whether later assertions can be violated — must be inspected to decide reachability.
- Build-configuration macros (MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS, MHD_USE_W32_THREADS, HAVE_LISTEN_SHUTDOWN, EPOLL_SUPPORT, HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, DAUTH_SUPPORT): these control which blocks are compiled in; to decide whether code shown is actually present in the build (and thus subject to MISRA unreachable-code rule) you must know their definitions.
- MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY and MHD_USE_TLS (option bits/macros): used in assertions/conditions that select code paths; their values in daemon->options affect reachability of branches (e.g. select-vs-threaded paths, TLS cleanup).
- shutdown and SHUT_RDWR: presence (via HAVE_LISTEN_SHUTDOWN) and semantics determine whether the shutdown(fd,...) calls exist and are reachable.

Providing these symbols (definitions and semantics) lets an analyser determine which branches are compiled in and which runtime conditions can actually occur, so it can conclude whether any portion of MHD_stop_daemon is provably unreachable (violating the MISRA rule).
